title: Illegal BASE jumper calls police after cell tower mishap
text:
A BASE jumper who jumped illegally from a northwestern Wisconsin cellphone tower ended up calling the police on himself after his parachute became caught on a guy wire, leaving him dangling perilously 50 feet from the ground.

Police say the 20-year-old man was floating back to earth after jumping from the 300-foot Charter Communications tower in Menomonie, 70 miles east of Minneapolis, on Thursday morning, when the descent came to a sudden and abrupt halt.

Bath's parachute became tangled up in the guy lines of the transmitter leaving him in a rather embarrassing but also dangerous position.

After his rescue at around 9:30am, Mason Barth, of Neillsville, was treated for injuries at a local hospital and then released whereupon he was arrested for criminal trespass of a transmission company.

A BASE jumper had to rescued in the city of Menomonie, Wisconsin after he became tangled in guy wires of a 300 ft transmission tower that he jumped from

It left Mason Barth dangling some 50 feet above ground and he had to call police for help

Firefighters were greeted with quite the sight as the BASE jumper was left hanging from wires

The BASE jumper was ultimately rescued by a bucket truck after his chute got tangled

Barth had jumped from the top of the transmission tower but just seconds later his gliding back to earth came to a sudden stop

'I'd just like to say thanks to everybody who was there and helped me,' Barth said. 'Without them, you know, I might not be here today.'

BASE jumping stands for building, antenna, span and earth - the four common objects from which BASE jumpers launch their descent.

'I'd just like to say thanks to everybody who was there and helped me,' Barth said to CBS News. 'Without them, you know, I might not be here today.'

According to the complaint, his parachute 'deployed incorrectly' and caused him to collide with the cables.

'It ended bad,' he said.

'It's just something I love doing. I'm really passionate about it,' Barth said. 'Base jumping is a dangerous sport and I don't recommend anybody doing it. I'm not going to be doing that for a long time.'

If convicted, Barth could face up to six years in prison and/or a $10,000 fine.

Barth was arrested for criminal trespass of a transmission company

Barth is something of a daredevil. Here he is pictures standing in the middle of train tracks
description: A 20-year-old base jumper from western Wisconsin who got caught in cable wires after leaping off a 300-foot high tower is facing a felony charge. Mason Barth, of Neillsville, was charged Friday.
